dt: {bc}a descendant of a wealthy, aristocratic, or influential family
{bc}a detached living portion of a plant (such as a bud or shoot) joined to a stock in grafting and usually supplying solely aerial parts to a graft

et: Middle English {it}sioun, syon{/it} "branch, twig, offshoot," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}cioun, ciun, sioun{/it} (continental Old French {it}cion{/it} "offspring, new growth of a plant") from {it}ci-,{/it} going back to an Old Low Franconian outcome of West Germanic {it}*kīþa-{/it} "sprout, bud" + Old French {it}-on,{/it} suffix, perhaps here with diminutive value, going back to Latin {it}-ōn-, -ō,{/it} suffix of nouns denoting persons with a prominent feature; {it}*kīþa-{/it} "sprout, bud" (whence also Old English {it}cīþ{/it} "sprout, shoot, bud," Old Saxon {it}kīth{/it} "shoot," Old High German {it}kīd,{/it} also {it}-kīdi{/it} in {it}frumikīdi{/it} "first one"), going back to Indo-European {it}*ǵei̯H-ti-{/it} or {it}*ǵiH-ti-,{/it} noun derivative of a verbal base {it}*ǵei̯H-{/it} "burst out, sprout," whence, from a nasal present, Germanic {it}*kīnan-{/it} (whence Old English {it}cīnan{/it} "to burst open, gape, [of skin] be chapped," Old Saxon {it}kīnan{/it} "to sprout," Old High German {it}chīnan{/it} "to sprout, germinate," Swedish dialect {it}kina{/it} "to yawn," Gothic {it}keinan{/it} "to sprout," {it}uskeinan{/it} "to put forth, send out [growth]," with past participle {it}uskijanata{/it} lacking {it}-n-{/it}); whence also, with suffixed {it}*-d{sup}h{/sup}-,{/it} Latvian {it}ziêdu, ziêdêt{/it} "to bloom," Lithuanian {it}žydė́ti{/it}

The Anglo-French forms are taken from the {it}Oxford English Dictionary,{/it} third edition, though their source is unspecified; the {it}Anglo-Norman Dictionary{/it} lacks an entry for this word. The suffix should perhaps be taken as filling out a word that otherwise has little phonetic substance. — Another generally cited nominal derivative of the Germanic verb is represented by Old English {it}cine, cinu{/it} (weak feminine noun) "chink, fissure" (compare {et_link|chink:1|chink:1}), Middle Dutch {it}kēne{/it} "cleft, crack." Armenian {it}cil{/it} "stem, bud, top of a crop plant" has also been adduced, though Martirosyan ({it}Etymological Dictionary of the Armenian Inherited Lexicon,{/it} Brill, 2009) believes that "I[ndo-]E[uropean] proposals are not convincing."
shortdef: descendant, child; especially : a descendant of a wealthy, aristocratic, or influential family
a detached living portion of a plant (such as a bud or shoot) joined to a stock in grafting and usually supplying solely aerial parts to a graft
